results.title: Top of the Town cinema slide
results.brief_description: Glass Cinema Lantern slide with black edging tape. This hand coloured slide is an advertisement for the film ‘Top of the Town’ featuring Doris Nolan by Universal Pictures.

results.title: Under the Clock cinema slide
results.brief_description: Glass Cinema lantern slide with black edging tape and internal black frame. This hand coloured slide is an advertisement for the film ‘Under the Clock’ featuring Judy Garland by Metro Goldwyn Mayer Ltd. A piece of light brown tape has been adhered to the top edge of the image to cover session times.

results.title: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit glass slides (Sea Life)
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description: There are five parts to the Sea Life slides, each slide has 4 images. These small slides have red sealing tape around the edges. These slides form part of The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit with removable chimney and internal wooden block. The lantern is housed in original box with metal handle, and internal red and blue graphic for: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit. 20 glass slides in custom box, length of textile to keep box shut, 2 small empty boxes which act to store slides in a snug manner.

results.title: Autograph
results.brief_description: One of 6 works selected by AIM director David Atkinson as representing the best interactive work produced by the AIM centre up until 2004. An interactive work focusing on the use of eloquent graphics and innovative interface screen design for navigation. The work deals with themes such as humanity, organics and technology. A beautiful work pioneering elegant design with an innovative interface. Invited for exhibition at the Young Talent Pavilion in MILIA, France in 1995.

results.title: Whitefellanormal
results.creator_credit: Vernon Ah Kee, ACMI and SBS Independent
results.material_description: single channel digital video, colour, sound, 30 min duration
results.brief_description: Vernon Ah Kee’s seething representation of contemporary Australian black/white politics playfully uses language, moving text and self-portraiture to deadly serious effect.

results.title: Postcard from Tunis
results.brief_description: The central theme of ‘Postcard from Tunis’ is writing itself - its histories, its inscriptions and its relevance to the human-computer interface. This is explored in a personal, audiovisual portrait of Tunis, the home of my family-in-law. I designed and programmed the unique interface so that it echoes an actual visit, where you can’t help learning a few Tunisian words and with time, starting to read written Arabic. Although the work was designed for adults, children have shown a strong affinity with it.
